habitat_description:
S. aberti is found primarily in ponderosa pine forests and woodlands (Nash and Seaman, 1977; Dodd et al., 2003; Keith, 2003). The subspecies kaibabensis and introduced populations have been observed in mixed-conifer forests of Douglas-fir, quaking aspen, Englemann spruce, blue spruce, subalpine fir, white fir, and southwestern white pine (Findley et al., 1975; Hall, 1981; Hutton et al., 2003; Edelman and Koprowski, 2005) as well as in pinyon-juniper woodlands (Reynolds, 1966; Ratcliff et al., 1975; Soderquist, 1987), though typically within close proximity to stands of ponderosa.

The species avoids open woodlands and savannas, requiring corridors of interlocking canopies (Keith, 2003) or a minimum canopy cover of 40-50% (Prather et al., 2006).
